TopicTitle: Buff all radial engines to be just as good as other engines

Articles.Content:
I'm sick of having to use a rockomax 48-7s because its radial counterpart is extremely underpowered. It's unrealistic and stupid.(Not angry, just a bit annoyed in case anyone asks)

Edited August 1, 2014 by JokingHinge

At one time, the devs specifically stated that they wanted to keep radials a little weaker than the stack mounted engines because it's always easy to find room for more radial engines, and they didn't want there to be no reason to use the stack mounted engines.

Well, as someone with OCD, my brain gets overloaded whenever I read the stats, so I quit ksp for a day and come back. I just tend to put two 48-7s engines on cubic octagonal struts and just wonder what it would be like if my OCD allowed me to make a pretty rocket.

I've just changed them:

48-7S: 25kN Thrust, 0.15t weight, 300 Atm ISP, 350 Vac ISP

24-77: 20kN Thrust, 0.125t weight, 300 Atm ISP, 350 Vac ISP

The only difference is the 24-77 has slightly lower TWR

Well, as someone with OCD, my brain gets overloaded whenever I read the stats, so I quit ksp for a day and come back. I just tend to put two 48-7s engines on cubic octagonal struts and just wonder what it would be like if my OCD allowed me to make a pretty rocket.

I feel like the 48-7S is overpowered, and I have used 24-77s for several excellent designs, including as the only rocket engines on my first working stock SSTO spaceplane.

Also you can make your rocket prettier by mounting the engines on Clamp-o-trons Jr. instead of Cubic Octagonal Struts.

It's for ballancing. You can place them anywhere, so to compenstate, they are a little weaker.

If it bothers you so much, why don't you just change them? It's only a few vallues in the part files
Well, I guess using cubic octagonal struts is cheating, so I am just gonna do it the normal way from now on.
